Therefore, the patient will need a complete blood count (CBC) routinely to monitor for this potential adverse effect. Basic metabolic panel and hemoglobin A1c are not typically relevant to monitoring for clozapine. Dexamethasone suppression test is not relevant to bipolar disorder or clozapine treatment.

Clozapine can cause agranulocytosis, a potentially fatal condition in which the body stops producing enough white blood cells to fight off infections. Therefore, patients taking clozapine need to have their complete blood count monitored weekly for the first 6 months of treatment, then every 2 weeks for the next 6 months, and then monthly thereafter. Option A and C are not necessary for monitoring the medication adjustment, and option D is used to diagnose Cushing's syndrome, which is not relevant to this patient's case.
